product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: A Very Satisfied Customer
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 9, 2023
text: I am writing this review specifically for one major reason. Tech reviewers on YouTube and elsewhere are wont to tell you that a 27" 1440p monitor is now the "sweet spot" and should now be the standard monitor size for work and gaming. A few will tell you they can't use anything less than a 32" monitor. Well, I have a 32" monitor and I've tried a 27" monitor too. Actually I recently bought two 27" monitors, but I quickly returned them. My 32" monitor is in one of my bedrooms, and I use it every now and then.Is a 24" monitor big enough for work and play? YES. Plenty! Some folks use a 13" laptop for all their computer tasks. The biggest laptop in the world at this moment is the Acer Predator 21X, which has a curved 21" screen. So, everyone who uses a laptop for their computer tasks (and there a many, very many people who work this way), do so on computer screens less then a 24" monitor. As far as I know, there are no monitors at my place of work bigger than 24". In one Gadget Review article, Lawrence Bonk wrote, "Professional gamers nearly always use 24-inch monitors instead of larger monitors."Before I go further, let me quickly say that a 24" 1080p monitor may very well be the perfect size for any type of task you perform on a computer. It has plenty of screen real estate, and it is not overwhelming. Monitors of this size are cheaper too. A 24" monitor doesn't have much of the wasted spaces I found on my 27" 1440p monitors.This 24" HP monitor has two built-in speakers (thank you, HP!). Yes, I often connect my PC via Bluetooth to my JBL Partybox 310, but I love that I have an option of using the speakers in my monitor.I did not like how texts appeared on my 27" 1440p monitors. Because of the higher pixel density, the texts were smaller than they appeared on this HP monitor, forcing me to scale up text and picture sizes on the 27" monitors. Without even tweaking the settings on this 24" monitor, pictures and texts were just right. I also played some videos on both the 27" 1440p monitor and this 24" 1080p monitor. And frankly, the quality was either practically the same on both or even better on this 24" 1080p monitor.I don't game. I use my computer for everyday, ordinary tasks (emails, study, paying bills, shopping, VoIP calls, video calls, video conferencing, work-related tasks, web surfing, playing music, and watching videos and movies). I can report confidently that not only is this 24" monitor adequate for these tasks, I also prefer this monitor to the 27" 1440p monitor (which I have already returned).Presently, I use two of this 24" monitors in an "Extend these displays," dual monitor setup. I love it, but just one monitor would have been adequate for my needs. Some bloggers are adamant that having three monitors is the best for productivity, but I found that to be counterproductive. Not only does a three-monitor setup require more desk space, it also becomes a distraction. I kept asking myself, "What should I display on the third monitor?" The third monitor was totally dispensable.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Good monitor for the price, despite backlight failure at 9 months
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 19, 2023
text: I bought this to enhance my WFH setup and return my work monitor to my actual office setup. Out-of-the-box assembly was pretty quick - take it out, stick the stand on, plug and play.It did take some adjustment in the on-screen menu to get the settings right. I thought the defaults a bit rough. But once the sharpness and black settings were tweaked, it was quite good. I don’t know that I would use this for hefty graphics work, but as a side monitor for watching YouTube and responding to email, it’s great for the price.After 627 hours of use, it suffered a backlight failure (picture of the failure against the backdrop of my attempt to chat with them attached). As I’m under warranty, I reached out to support. Typical large-company support situation - time-consuming and near-painful tier 1 support, having me restart and change settings. After two hours they agreed to send me a box, citing a 8-10 day turnaround. Honestly, I’m debating just buying another (or this or another brand) and calling it a day. If they find it’s damaged then I’m on the hook. I can’t fathom it would be as it hasn’t moved in 9 months.But I recognize I’m more the exception than the rule. For its price, it’s a nice, name-brand monitor for day-to-day use.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Very impressive
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 9, 2023
text: I've only had the monitor for a short time, so maybe reliability could become an issue, but this is an amazing visual experience. I mostly watch old TV shows and movies so the color isn't as critical as it might be to some, but the color quality on 30 year old movies is excellent. What I can't believe is the clarity of watching old shows like Perry Mason and Dick Van Dyke. Extremely pleased.I should also comment on the volume control, as I struggled to understand it. This was part of a review written by Lindguini, so I'm plagiarizing:HOW TO FIX LOW VOLUME SOUND: The built-in speakers are better than some reviewers indicate. I believe most people don't discover that the monitor menu has its own volume control that's set to 50% volume by factory default. If you just connect this monitor to the PC you'll automatically get sound through the HP speakers via HDMI or DisplayPort (you only have to use the separate audio cable when using the VGA input). But no matter how high you turn up your PC volume control, you'll only get 50% volume from the monitor's speakers which is why people complain about low volume. To fix this, all you need to do is go to the "Management" tab of the monitor menu, select "Audio", and then turn up the volume control from 50 (default) to 100 and you'll find the monitor speakers are plenty loud. After that, you'll only have to use your PC volume control as normal.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Great monitor + 75Hz + HOW TO FIX LOW VOLUME SOUND
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 10, 2020
text: This HP 24mh monitor has a clear, crisp display and is the perfect size for desktop use (not too big, not too small).  It accepts both HDMI and DisplayPort inputs (and even VGA for old school PCs).  While Windows will select 60Hz refresh rate by default, you can go into Windows' display settings and select 75Hz refresh rate for this monitor.  The 75Hz refresh rate really does help smooth out motion.  You should also go into the monitor's "Image" menu setting and set Response Time to Level 3 which provides the best VSYNC performance.  One of the best features that places this monitor above and beyond its price range is the 90-degree rotating screen, height adjustment, and swiveling base.  The stand is rock-solid without any wobble.  The speakers are just fine once you discover the menu control I explain below:HOW TO FIX LOW VOLUME SOUND:  The built-in speakers are better than some reviewers indicate.  I believe most people don't discover that the monitor menu has its own volume control that's set to 50% volume by factory default.  If you just connect this monitor to the PC you'll automatically get sound through the HP speakers via HDMI or DisplayPort (you only have to use the separate audio cable when using the VGA input).  But no matter how high you turn up your PC volume control, you'll only get 50% volume from the monitor's speakers which is why people complain about low volume.  To fix this, all you need to do is go to the "Management" tab of the monitor menu, select "Audio", and then turn up the volume control from 50 (default) to 100 and you'll find the monitor speakers are plenty loud.  After that, you'll only have to use your PC volume control as normal.This is a great quality monitor with features beyond its price range.  Fantastic value, HP!ADDITIONAL NOTE:  HP sells an identical monitor to the HP 24mh under the model P24h.  The only difference is that the P24h has a black plastic logo strip along the bottom instead of silver like the 24mh.  Everything else is identical (specs, speakers, height adjustable stand, etc.) plus the P24h comes with both an HDMI cable and a DisplayPort cable.

title: HDMI for Video and PC Speakers for, well, you know. Doesn't keep that info saved.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 15, 2022
text: This is from my Son..Hello, Update: I really don't like the back speakers.  I've upped the volume in the button prefs, but I won't be buying another Monitor where they're in the back.  The colors are fantastic.  If I use the DisplayPort, when switching to a game I discovered I have to press the power button on the monitor, let the light go out and press it again to turn on again.  The has returned!  If I exit a game, and go back to Desktop, I usually have to repeat that process.  Using HDMI...zero problems. I have an odd setup, and I wanted to keep the Motherboard Stereo vs GeForce 780's HDMI sound.  But the Monitor kept switching back to HDMI for both every time I turned it off, then later on again.  I then had to go into Monitor settings and change it again.  I, honestly, forgot that my nVIDIA board has HDMI in the video hardware.  Otherwise, this Monitor is doing everything is should and doing it well.  Since nothing is perfect (done, complete, cannot be added to...final).  I would suggest that HP rethinks where the speakers are located.  I'd prefer them to be in the front.  You loose some decibels when they're in the back.  If you're in an Apartment, having the speakers in the back could be less helpful (which I am).  I'm considering doing a cheap fix, "route" the sound to the sides...to the front.  Otherwise, I really dig this Monitor. Windows 7 looks / sounds great with it.  Yep, I still adore that version of Windows.  10, horrible GUI, 11...is a little better.  I had to install Realtek's HD Audio driver for all 3 OSes to get the PC Speakers to function.  Once I remembered the nVIDIA has HDMI, I bought a DVI to HDMI..and went that way.  I also disabled the Autio-Switch before doing that.  They have the good fine-tuning controls which makes things sweet. Only problem is...it doesn't save ("remember") settings.  So that's something they might consider looking into...for oddballs.  HA! I haven't been a fan of HP in many years since their products have become cheap and unreliable for many years.  Before then, they were a GREAT brand.  Since the new printer with the long lasting Ink was released, and my Mother loves it, and since I'm her Tech, I've used it often and it's doing better than 2 other versions of Printers.  So, after checking the reviews here...I thought I'd go ahead and give this a go.  I'll check back later and update after some months.

text: I like this monitor. I love the height adjustment! It will be so much nicer than bending my neck to look down at my all-in-one. Hard to find a height adjustable monitor at this price.I did have a bit of trouble getting the operating manual. Spent way too much time looking for a manual for this model on the HP website. FINALLY noticed Get Product Support on the order details page. I soon talked with a very nice human being who sent me a cut and paste address for the manual.Unfortunately, I haven't gotten to use it much, other than to check screen quality. I ordered an HP desktop from another vendor at the same time. In my quest to get some questions answered about the computer, I found that HP had no record of the computer's serial number. After some googling, I found that is a thing with HP. They don't have a very reliable system for keeping track of their serial numbers. AND, if you have no serial number, there is no way to communicate with HP. Plus, you have no warrantee. Many people find out they have no valid serial number too late. Even the tech guy at the store where I bought the computer had had the same problem. He spent months (in vain) trying to get satisfaction from HP. I am still looking for a NON HP desktop.

text: Honestly the only reason im writing this review is to share how helpful the helpline was at well.... helping.Had this guy as a secondary display for about 2-3 weeks and it worked perfectly. Unfortunately today as i turned it on, the screen remained black and buttons stopped working. I switched the display type from HDMI to display port and it still didn't work. After a few more attempts there was no luck, and the display was simply bricked. The part i appreciate is that the dude was not only very very helpful and chill, but they are sending me a new monitor immediately.That whole process, plus the fact that it does exactly what is expected when working is why i gave 5 stars.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Excellent monitor for general use and streaming video
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2021
text: Like many people, my wife has been working at home during the pandemic. She's got a nice ThinkPad and I provided her with a Shure MV51 microphone to give her that big radio voice in Zoom meetings, and a USB Docking station (Plugable brand) which as the capability of dual 4K monitors, so I decided to buy this HP monitor to compliment the 10 year old 22" ASUS HDMI monitor she had been using. Well, I was totally blown away at how monitor technology has advanced. The resolution on the monitors is the same (1080p) but if you click on the photo, you'll see that the black levels on the new monitor just blow the old one away. This is the reason why Plasma displays dominated high end TV for a while because LCD displays could not deliver the contrast ratios for home theater. Granted, if you're just working on an Excel spreadsheet, reading email or in a Zoom meeting, the difference doesn't matter much. But if you want to take a lunch break and watch a 20 minute episode of your favorite TV show on Hulu, the difference is obvious. I did not give this a rating for gaming, as this wasn't tested and it's not a gaming monitor to begin with. Another nice feature is that it is height adjustable, so no more putting your monitor on a stack of books to raise it a couple of inches. I does have speakers that play through the HDMI input, but they are not as loud as a typical phone. The speakers are good enough for viewing a video or doing a Zoom meeting in a quiet environment, but that's about it. Because the border around the screen is so thin, expect any webcam to intrude a little on the top of the screen. It also uses a standard PC power cord and not a "wall wart" power supply. Many new monitors are moving towards this and I don't know if it is a blessing or a curse. The upside is that you can use a standard power cord and not have an external power power supply hanging under your desk. The downside is that if the power supply carps out, you can't replace it - you have it repaired (highly unlikely these days) or replace the entire monitor. If you thought my review was helpful, click on the "Helpful" button!

title: Low Volume Fix - Monitor Management Function Button Location
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2022
text: Another reviewer mentioned a way to increase the volume on the built in speakers (as the factory default setting is set at only 50%) and mentioned monitor "management".  For the life of me, I could not find this option in Windows 10.  I was getting ready to return the monitor but just for kicks, I decided to look at the Users Manual.  (who reads these things these days anyway, especially for a monitor?).  Lo and behold, there are actual physical buttons hidden away on the bottom right corner of the monitor that activates the "monitor management" function that is independent of the Computer Operating System.  Press the one on the far left to get into this mode (see second photo).  From here you can get into various modes one of which is to change the default volume setting.  See attached photos.  I hope this will save others who are puzzled as to why in the heck is the volume so low from the monitor speakers.

text: I'm very happy with this monitor.  I was able to try it out at a former employer's office.  At home, I had a larger monitor and unfortunately, larger isn't always better.I like this size of this display.  My monitor is only about 24" away from my face and I have decent vision with diminishing reading vision.  Looking at a larger monitor was more than annoying, it just wasn't good to use and it made me not want to use my home computer.Using this monitor at 1920 x 1080 (recommended for this screen), and having the magnification set to 100% (Control Panel > Appearance and Personalization > Display = "smaller") is great!I don't do gaming and I haven't used the internal speakers.  Can't rate those.I sometimes change the color settings to help minimize the impact on viewing screens late at night (Warm, Neutral, Cool, Low Blue Light, Night, Reading, HP Enhance +, or Custom RGB).  This is helpful.I am able to tilt the screen down and up with ease.  And the rotate to portrait is great (raise display to highest settings and tilt back to clear the desk), but my old laptop can't change the settings to view in portrait.I recommend this monitor.  It's great that it can also go on a stand that holds double screens.  And with the very thin left and right frame sides, it would be a great monitor to use 2 or 3 side-by-side.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Decent for the money
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2023
text: Decent monitor for the money. Does everything it is supposed to. In my opinion it is a pretty good deal, especially since it comes with the height adjust stand with rotation. The colors are fairly vibrant and the display is bright, which I like.The only problem I have with this display is the quality of the LCD panel. Out of the box, mine had a noticeable bright-spot on right of the display. Annoying, but not intolerable. Additionally, the coating on the display is very good at picking up reflections. I would not recommend using this in a bright, sunny room. Some light is fine, but bright light sources (like the sun or a nearby lamp) will reflect annoyingly well. Finally, this display has fairly poor blacks. My other display (an Acer B243HL, which is too old to even have HDMI) has better blacks, which is disappointing.Overall, a good display for the money. Not ideal for fancy-pants professional work where colors need to be spot on, but no one doing that stuff would buy a $150 monitor. But it is more than capable at completing everyday tasks, so I would say it is fine.

text: My old display died yesterday.  This display was the right price for the right features and available in one day by Amazon Prime.  I recommend getting the instructions from HP online as the one-sheet instructions with pictures only is severely lacking.  The only issue I had was with the audio.  It comes with a audio cable with phone plugs on each end.  If you use this in conjunction with HDMI, you get no sound.  I found nothing that specifically said that in the instructions, but while trying to figure out why the built-in speakers weren't working, I unplugged the audio cable and immediately the sound worked.  It seems the HDMI cables carry the sound and the audio cable is not only not required, but blocks the audio signal.HP should update their instructions to make that clear.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Great value for the features
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2020
text: I selected this monitor because it has both HDMI and DisplayPort inputs, (it also has VGA, but I'll never use it) has a stand that will rotate to 90, allows for VESA mounting without blocking inputs, is 24" diag. with small bezels, is 1920x1080, and is an established brand. It is all of these, no problem. What you also get is tool-free installation (nice to have even if you have plenty of tools), and cables! I expect a power cord with anything that uses power, but I did not expect an HDMI cable. It did not come with a DisplayPort cable, but I hooked one (of the two I bought) via miniDP, and a full-sized cable would have just gone into the parts pile.  Six-foot HDMI cables are a great item to have laying around.It also came with an 1/8" stereo patch cable for analog audio. I saw the description about speakers, but didn't intend to use that feature. I didn't even hook up the cable. What surprised me was when the monitor I hooked up via HDMI started playing sound from the laptop. This feature does not seem to be mentioned anywhere in this product description, nor even in the user manual, but this thing does HDMI audio extraction! I haven't yet tried, but I think you could hook up a Chromecast and get the full audio/video experience. That said, there does not seem to be much of an amplifier -- it's not loud, even with the volume cranked all the way up on the PC (there is no on-monitor volume control). In any case, it's a nice bonus. I didn't buy this thing for the speakers, but their presence doesn't bother me. The display portion of the monitor is fairly thin. The speakers do add a bit of girth, but no more than you would have from a similarly-featured (no audio) 24" monitor from a few years ago. Same goes for weight. I generally use Dell 24" monitors, and this HP model holds up well against the Dell models that are significantly more expensive (and have not dropped features like VESA mounting and 90 rotating base support).Bottom line: I'm thrilled to get a high quality 24" 1920x1080 monitor with VESA mounting, 90 rotating base, and both HDMI and DisplayPort, and even giddy about the included HDMI cable and speakers, all for $110.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)

title: Beware:  May not be compatible with Windows 11
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2022
text: I believe this monitor model precedes the Windows 11 launch.  It worked very well with my Dell business lap-top running Windows 10:  great picture, adjustable stand.  However, when connecting to my home Dell PC running Windows 11, my desktop functionality was limited.  I had all of my desktop short-cuts and they worked, but all of the icons and functionality on the lower taskbar were missing, including the Start button.  There were other issues also.  I checked the HP website for any monitor drivers and found that none were available for Windows 11 (only Windows 10) with a note that if the OS driver was not available, then the monitor may not be compatible.  I then switched back to the old monitor, re-booted, and the same errors occurred and appeared to be permanent.  Possibly, the monitor installed some plug and play software that corrupted the Windows 11 files.  This was the conclusion reached by the Dell techs helping.  After a couple hours of troubleshooting, we had to re-install Windows 11 to get it back working.  I've returned the monitor and am looking for a newer model.

text: As someone who just started working from home, it was imperative that I get two good working monitors. I love it so much and it has exceeded my expectations, and I only bought them for $109.99 each! I never had an HP computer before, so I am definitely pleased. But I saw some other reviews and was able to toggle the menu and adjust the audio for both monitors, so I am able to get really good sound! Also, if you want to change the refresh rate, literally all you have to do is download Graphics Command Center on the Microsoft Store, go to Display settings and literally adjust the monitors refresh rate from there. BAM! 75 HzThe only reason why I am giving it four stars is because I wish there were more USB ports on the monitors. I realize now I may actually never use the VGA port...also, I am not certain the warranty on these devices, especially from Amazon, will totally help me if anything were to happen to these monitors.But so far, I AM VERY PLEASED WITH MY PURCHASE. :)

Originally, I thought the speakers just simply didn’t work.I contacted tech support and they had me try a different cord but never asked me about HDMI. So, although she was very nice, she had no idea what she was doing aside from reading a script. They need to add the HDMI issue their script. A note on the site itself might be a good idea as well. Anyway, she set up a return that I later cancelled (they never told UPS that I cancelled so he showed up for a return the next - actually, that was wrong as well since I couldn’t return it till the new one arrived - oh well...)Anyway, after I sat and thought about it for a while, I suspected that the HDMI carrying the audio signal thereby blocking it. So, I used the VGA connection. It works, but I had to significantly adjust the vertical setting on the monitor.Bottom line, the monitor is now fully functional including the speakers. The speakers sound pretty much like any other PC speakers although a tad louder, certainly loud enough for my use. I was able to tweak the sound a bit with the audio manager that came with the Lenovo computer. The point I deducted was for the tech support. I realize this is a new monitor but the people answering the phone should at least understand the technology even if they don’t know the item details.UPDATE 1: The monitor does NOT work well unless I use an HDMI cable, which I am now doing. So, I am back to external speakers. Basically, if I try to use anything other than an HDMI cable, the monitor cuts out (goes dark) frequently, although it does come back on again. BOTTOM LINE: I am not able to use the internal soeakers, perhaps you’ll have better luck...

title: Macbook users - you have nothing to worry about!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 1, 2021
text: Bought this to use as a monitor for my 2017 MacBook Air as the 13" screen was starting to strain my eyes. For some context, I'm a student and my primary use for the screen is to read read read and take lots of notes. I've read a few reviews about issues with the resolution from a mac to this screen, and the surefire way to make sure none of those issues happen is to buy a thunderbolt to hdmi cable - I bought one from amazon basics a couple years ago and it works seamlessly - edge to edge display and full resolution. It's not a 4k monitor or anything but with how big it is and how far back you sit, it's all the same in terms of crisp, clear picture. I don't use my computer for gaming really so I cannot comment on the graphics/resolution for that purpose - but for your basic office or school work - it's perfect.Not sure what a solution would be for newer mac models that have only the usb-c output. Also, this was bought in Feb 2021 and it seems like the latest model comes with built in speakers, has a tilt feature, and vertical sliding to adjust the height. For this price, I think the value is unbeatable. The only downside is that there seems to be no external volume control, but I have my bluetooth headphones in most of the time anyway so it doesn't matter. It also comes with an aux cord to connect to external speakers, and a regular hdmi cable.If you're hesitating on this product, there's a reason it's the #1 seller on computer monitors on amazon!

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Great monitor with caveat and horrible customer service from HP
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on December 15, 2020
text: Bought this monitor to go side by side with my Samsung 27" (which I've had for over 7 years). Color was beautiful, read review on how to change from default 60 hz refresh rate to 75 hz and all was well until I reached up to tilt it from the top: BEWARE there is almost NO bevel at the top and edges and touching the screen it broke (sent lines across top and down the center). I had only had it for 26 days. Called Amazon and they said to call HP since it was within the 30 days. HP rep said broken screen was not covered and offered to send me a replacement for the exact price as on Amazon (new) and take 8-10 days to get it to me, PLUS return broken one at my own expense. Thanks, but NO thanks. Called Amazon back on day 30 and told them what HP said and they offered a full refund or replacement with 2-day shipping. They asked me to return the broken one at their cost.  The entire phone conversation took 15 minutes. This is why I am still a Prime customer after almost 20 years. They know how to treat customers.This is a fabulous screen for the price and I could find no others on Amazon in this price range with speakers and 75 hz RR. I did take the replacement, which was here as promised 2 days later and returned the broken one the next day.  Just be careful and only hold the screen on the back and bottom, beveled-edge as the least amount of pressure will crack the screen and that is not covered with Amazon's extra warranty through Assurion nor will HP cover it.

title: Got a dud monitor, and HP's customer support stinks
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2023
text: I had this monitor set up for about two weeks when it developed a darker/gray area in the lower left corner of the screen. It was just noticeably darker than the rest of the screen no matter what I did to the brightness. Unfortunately I'd dragged my feet setting it up, so the return window had just expired and Amazon directed me to HP since it was under warranty, but assured me they would provide a refund if HP couldn't solve the problem.Spent 45 minutes on the phone with HP trouble shooting. Seemed to resolve the dark area, but in the process, managed to create a much bigger problem. The monitor would just black out entirely after 5-7 minutes regardless of whether I was using it or not. Whatever I had open on that screen would just get stuck there - it wouldn't come back to my laptop or my other external monitor unless I disconnected it. Went through the reset steps 3-4 times and got it back online, but was really frustrated. The fifth time, the monitor blacked out and wouldn't come back on at all except in super brief flashes when I unplugged and replugged the HDMI cable. 30 more minutes on the phone with HP - I have to send it back to them and hopefully will get a replacement in 2-3 weeks (4-6 business days after they receive the original monitor from me).I thought this would be a nice upgrade to get me a full dual monitor set-up alongside a very basic Acer monitor. I'd by far recommend an Acer over this.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Great for productivity
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2020
text: I bought two of these, and they have been great.  I like the input options, and that the monitors have speakers.  I'm no audiophile, so having simple speakers included in the monitors meant I could have one less item on my desk.I put these on the "Mount it!" dual VESA mount (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B08BW739D2/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1), which was super easy.  The monitors came with a very nice, sturdy, flat-base (So you don't totally lose that desk space!!) stand, but I opted for the mount.  The monitors also came with VESA screws already installed, so mounting them just required removal of the screws and reinstallation of the screws with the VESA mount plate.Also, I have been working from home, and had one these hooked up to both my personal computer and my work computer.  Switching inputs was easy using the hard-key buttons hidden on the bottom-right of the monitor body.And as simple as it is, these came with an HDMI an power cable which were 6ft long each, which was nice.  NOTE: The listing says 75hz refresh rate, but that is with DisplayPort cables.  As I write this, these are running at 60hz on the included HDMI cables.  This doesn't matter at all to me, because I don't play games on them, but FYI!I shop around pretty extensively before making purchases, and I feel confident that these are a good value (obviously, since I bought them).  $110 for a brand-name, 1080p, 60/75hz IPS monitor with speakers, VESA mount-reay but comes with a good stand, and has good input options (HDMI, DP, or VGA).  Now that I've owned them for a few weeks, I would absolutely purchase them again next time.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: A very good value monitor
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2021
text: What this monitor is: a good general purpose monitor for document editing, email and web-browsing, or as a secondary monitor when you need a bit more screen space, which is my primary usage.  Especially at it's price point, it provides good value for general use.What it is not: a monitor for serious gaming, video or image editing.The controls provide a good deal of adjustment for image quality, tone and brightness, with menus that were easy enough to navigate to find what I wanted.  The "Low Blue Light," "Night" and "Reading settings are a plus.  Even if the out-of-the-box settings are your preferences, the adjustments are there.  Blacks could be darker, and the images a bit sharper, but the overall brightness and contrast are acceptable for general viewing.The sound is fine for general listening, whether music or videos on the web.  It's not quite as crisp and clear as the speakers on my high-end laptop, but are more than adequate for listening to news or podcasts on the web, or for some music while you work.The stand is a plus, sturdy, and adjustable for both height and tilt.  More surprising at this price was the option to rotate the screen for portrait orientation, which I occasionally need to do, and my reason for selecting this particular monitor.  That feature isn't common in this range, but made this purchase worthwhile.Overall, a very good value monitor with a strong feature set at a very affordable price.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: 75 Hertz and works great
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2020
text: Just received this HP 24mh FHD Monitor and set it up today. I saw some reviews that the refresh rate could not be set up to 75 hertz. I have a HDMI port on my Lenovo T480 laptop so I used a HDMI cable, connected it to this monitor, and the refresh rate showed up 75 hertz (see attached photo.)However, if I connect my HDMI cable to my USB C dongle (my dongle has a HDMI connection as well), the refresh rate can only be 60 hertz if connected to a dongle. I have a 2019 MacBook and it doesn't have HDMI connection so I use my USB C dongle to connect this HP monitor to my MacBook. The rate can be 60 hertz (see attached photo.)Therefore, my conclusion would be that you would need to have a direct HDMI connection directly connected your computer with the monitor. If you would use dongles, the refresh rate would be reduced.By the way, the shipping package is very well packed. A HDMI cable and a sound cable are included in the package, so it's very convenient. The Quick Setup Guide is very helpful, very easy to follow to set up the monitor.So far the monitor works great. It can be adjusted up and down and also tilt forward or backward just as it described on the product description on the Amazon website.Well, I just used it for a few hours. So far I’m very satisfied and I think this product is totally worth your money. It actually exceeds my expectation in many ways because the price is $109.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Pet owners think twice! It's an LCD.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 6, 2022
text: The picture quality is quite nice. A decent base gaming monitor. The screen has no bevels and breaks easily. Good midling grade monitor with FHD. Enjoyed monitor for approximately a year.This is an LCD monitor. I honestly didn't think that businesses bothered to make LCD monitors anymore since they're so dated, costly, and environmentally unfriendly. Unfortunately it's not stated anywhere in the description that it's an LCD monitor or I honestly wouldn't have purchased it. My purchase ended up having deadly consequences.My cat, Bagheera, suddenly decided he really liked my monitor (after a year of using it) and bit the corner cracking the screen. A couple days later he became very ill and stopped eating. He lost 25% of his body mass. I never suspected the screen.I brought him to the vet and had tests run. The vet said that he developed jaundice from rapidly losing weight. She said the tests showed no underlying illness. She questioned if he had come into contact with any poisonous materials. Not knowing my monitor was LCD and knowing Bagheera lived in a highly controlled environment, I said no. She said the only other likely cause would be a congenital defect. Bagheera went downhill quickly and needed to be put to sleep.My friend ended up questioning if biting the screen  hurt him. It then dawned on me that my monitor could possibly be an LCD. I knew the liquid layer of LCDs can contain around 30 toxic chemicals (including mercury). Turns out the monitor was an LCD. It was the only object in his limited environment that contained toxic substances. Which he also had contact with prior to illness. With LCDs being known to cause animal deaths and congenital defects more rare. I'm inclined to believe it was the monitor that harmed Bagheera.In the end,  it was a freak accident. No one's fault,except possibly my own. But I don't recommend pet owners risk it. You could be out a monitor, $500, and a loved companion.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Excellent value for money
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2021
text: Product: HP 24mh - 24 inch 1080p ips monitor.For the money, this is a really excellent monitor. I bought this because I needed a monitor for a 2-month stint working away from my regular "office", and I didn't want to spend much money for a short term need. I'm very impressed with how far my money stretched with this product.I'm mostly familiar with working with Dell Ultrasharp monitors, which are a higher-end product. A dell ultrasharp of the same size/resolution costs twice as much as this. For half the price, I would judge this HP monitor to have 90-95% as good a screen quality. It's clear, easy to look at, and not reflective at all. The colors are bright and there don't appear to be obvious limits to color gamut. Some cheap displays I've used have whacky blues/greens/yellows, but this monitor doesn't have any such problems.The build and stand feel like great quality, with sturdy mechanisms to assemble and move the screen around. If I had to pick one flaw, it would be that the stand seems to transmit a few vibrations from the table, resulting in the screen shaking when I'm typing too vigorously. This certainly won't affect my work, but for those who wish to furiously bash a keyboard while gaming, you might want a slightly more sturdy product.Ultimately, I've used similarly-priced displays with MUCH worse screens than this. So if you want quality without spending a lot, this is a great choice.

text: Since my new computer does not have a VGA port, it was time to replace my 19 inch LCD screen from the early 2000s which still works fine.  I have one of those adjustable desk tops so I waned an adjustable-height display to get the display to the right height.  I don't play games at all and am not a serious photographer so I don't really care about good performance or color accuracy.The display came sooner than promised and I was impressed with the no-tool setup.  Rotating it to the portrait mode requires you to tilt the screen first.I have my work computer on the VGA port and my new home computer on the HDMI port.  The sound is loud enough from both and I did not have to make any adjustments / selections to make it happen.  However, when the analog audio cable is plugged into my work computer, there is the occasional hissing/static sound (even when I am not playing any sound on the computer).  It is probably some kind of electric interference?  I tried repositioning the cable and that did not help.I am definitely more productive at work now given the larger screen.  The 24 inch size is perfect since it still shows most of my notebook computer screen (my adjustable table top is space-limited).

text: I ordered this monitor to add to my existing system as a second monitor under Windows 10.  It is a good looking monitor with very thin bezels on the top and sides. It is a very stark and pleasant difference compared to my older Dell monitor that has a thick bezel on all sides.The picture quality is good but not super.  I can compare it directly with my Dell monitor that sits right next to it.  I see the difference in sharpness as I drag any app from one screen to the other.  The Dell monitor is sharp and precise while the HP seems a bit fuzzier.  This is especially apparent at higher resolution with small text.  For anything else, it really is a good monitor (especially for the price).  Pictures look good and watching videos is also a good experience.The brightness is excellent does not get washed out, even with sunlight coming in the window.  The range between pure white and black is also very good.  Overall a good monitor for general usage and for business apps.  I don't play many games, so I can't comment on the response time of the monitor.

text: Just received this replacement monitor and am very pleased with the clarity and brightness of the screen.  I can't give a comprehensive review, as I just installed it.  I do have one criticism, not of the monitor itself, but of the information in the description.  I wanted the largest screen that would fit in my somewhat limited space and the product information indicated that it was close to 19" tall.  That was the very limit of my space.  However, it is an adjustable height and can be reduced to as low as 15" from the base.  So, had I known that, I would have probably purchased a larger monitor.  The actual graphic shows a measurement of 18.28 " but the line showing this vertical size is only along the edge of the monitor, implying the screen itself is 18.28".  That is very misleading.  The advertisement does say it is adjustable in height, but does not give any dimensions.  Purchasing an item without being able to see it in person is difficult and often leads to returns and dissatisfaction. I think this information would be very valuable to include in future ads.

title: Impressive display for the price
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2020
text: Got this gem a week ago. Setup was easy. I'm using this one as a second monitor attached to my laptop so I can use 3d modeling software. This monitor also has speakers in the rear, an interesting add-on.Pros: high quality image, clear picture, brightness, and accessible menu controls; screen can be adjusted on tilt and vertical axis (raised/lowered to eye level); excellent cost-to-value product for casual users to do business, browsing, etc. Would function fine for games but doesn't have the high resolution for most recent games based on 4K specs.Cons: some light bleed (about 1.5" on the right bezel) but not enough to warrant a return; cable ports can be hard to access, especially VGA given the need to screw the port head in (although HDMI is a simple insertion). I get why ports are positioned this way but I would hope in today's modern era they'd make it easier to insert a cable. Some may not like the adjustable height mechanism to raise/lower the display. Display cannot be rotated horizontally. It is fixed straight ahead.Despite these minor complaints, I love this monitor. At at time when monitors are headed to 4K and 8K resolutions, costing hundreds of dollars, the HP 24mh delivers impressive quality at a nice price.

title: Ordered 3 and one was broke.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 15, 2021
text: I ordered 3 because I am now working from home as a component designer I love these monitors they are crisp and clean and do not get smudged as easy. I received these last wednesday (2/10) I installed all three on my mount then turned them on to find one of the screens were broke. I filled out the replacement and rather it is amazon's settings or this companies I am very happy my replacement just arrived today monday (2/15). The replacement process was fast and easy i put the old broke one back in the box and went to ups and the scanned the code amazon gave me and thursday morning i received a notification that my replacement screen had shipped before i was even able to get the return in the mail. Before anyone says 4 days is not fast i live in the middle of nowhere wyoming and we have got a lot of snow. sorry for the length of this review but i needed to be said that this company stands behind their product and will do what they can to make things right and these are great monitors and quite large about 21"x13".

title: To get a big picture you have to overscan
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 11, 2021
text: When I hooked up this monitor the screen didn’t fill to the edges.  I played with the menu and found overscan enlarges the view past the edges of the screen.  In fact it enlarges it too much so I am using it with a 3/8” black margin all the way around.Yes it has speakers. Yes, I had to go in the menu and inform the monitor I wanted to use the green cable instead of the HDMI for the audio.  The only thing that bothers me is that the audio goes back to the HDMI default every time I power off the computer.I gave everything five stars because my beloved wife is planning to steal this monitor when I am not paying attention so I will probably buy another one.Update:  I was experiencing intermittent blinking of the monitor so I moved it to my wife’s computer and changed the monitor cable.  I now find the screen is filled completely and the blinking has stopped.  I am thinking that the video card in the computer contributes to this monitor’s performance.I remain happy with this purchase.

title: Don't buy this monitor for the built in speakers. Buy it for the amazing image quality.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 20, 2020
text: The monitor us a wonderful upgrade to my VGA 21 inch monitor.Overall visual design 5 stars.Speakers, and yes it has speakers. 1 star for size and placement. Use the monitor MENU to find AUDIO and adjust built in volume.If you are not using DP to DP as I am you may not have sound. Included with this monitor is a 3.5 to 3.5mm jumper cable. One end goes into the sound  out from the back of your desktop to the input of this monitor. Then you shall have a small amount of sound.Honestly, who places speakers facing the back. And, they are ridiculously small. The area they are in may be able to support much larger speakers.Sound quality is about like your phone on speaker only in stereo. The speaker size is about 1 inch or so. Facing back makes zero sense.If you look on the lower rounded back side you see where grills are. The tiny holes are where the speakers are.Do not buy this monitor for the built in speakers. They flat out suck.As for the picture/image on screen this is a fantastic monitor. 5 Stars.Recommendation: Yes.

title: Great value and performance.
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 8, 2021
text: I bought this monitor in December and, since it worked so well, another one in January. I am using to teach (college) from home with Zoom, and it allows me to share one of the screens while keeping the attendees in the other.Connection was a breeze. If you have a dual setup in a mac you will need an HDMI to Thunderbolt / USB4.The monitor position is adjustable, both vertically and turning. The lowest possible height is really low (1.5 inches), which is very convenient for desktop setups: a monitor stand will increase your desktop real state.The screen in pleasantly brilliant, and works best with the factory setups. Good resolution (native 1920x1080). It is not 4K, but who needs 4K anyway? With a dual setup, only one of the HDMI monitors will play sound (at least with Mac), and the sound quality is underwhelming. The volume is not adjustable through the monitor settings, and the source volume only goes that far. If you plan to use this for video conference plan to use a headset or external speakers.In balance, an excellent value monitor.

The only drawback is that I wish the monitor had a USB Type C input. I am using a Type C to HDMI adapter - this works, but somehow there is some power usage as the adapter is warm to the touch. Another point: for someone who wears polaroid glasses, the screen of HP 24mh is polarized and the screen is dark and you won't see a thing when the monitor is in the landscape position; you can rotate it 90 degrees to the portrait mode to make the screen image is visible. This is unlikely to be an issue for folks because polaroid lenses are in sunglasses - but I wish the manufacturers would mention this property or eliminate it (my Panasonic Lumix camera LCD display is also polarized and I can't see the screen in landscape mode when I am wearing my sunglasses outside)

title: Excellent Monitor
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 31, 2021
text: I had to replace my previous VGA monitor because I purchased a new hp desktop which was supposed to work with a VGA monitor, DID NOT.  Was going to return the computer, but decided to upgrade to this monitor.  Looks great, great picture, and easy to connect.This monitor has built in speakers, which is nice to eliminate the clutter of separate speakers and wires! On tip (that I luckily had read in a prior comment) is this:  The monitor comes with a speaker chord (thin green wire that connects the monitor to the computer).  If your computer automatically recognizes your new monitor/internal speakers, you do not need to connect the green wire to the monitor or computer.  IN FACT, if you do have it connected, the speaker does work!  So, don't connect the wire when you initially set up your monitor and check the sound.  If you don't have sound, THEN connect the green wire.

title: VGA Vertical Lines
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2022
text: I use this monitor as part of a multiple monitor setup with multiple laptops. I frequently change the inputs on the different monitors. While not a one button swap like my ViewSonic it is an easy two button change between input sources.One of my systems however was using a HDMI to VGA cable for the signal. Immediately I noticed vertical shadows going down the screen all the way across. The words in these shadows were also fuzzy. Meaning if reading an email part of the word would be slightly fuzzy while the other was crystal clear. This problem only occurred when using the VGA input. The HDMI input was fine. I then found a way to configure my system so the display port was used instead of VGA and there are no issues. Three stars because the shadows gave me an instant headache.Other than that I have had it for less than a day so I cannot say anything as to the quality.

title: Works well with Mac Mini and Apple keyboard
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2021
text: I bought two of these monitors for my new Mac Mini M1 and it works great, once you know how to set it up. In order for the speakers to work, I had to use the included audio jack wire to connect one of the monitors to the Mac Mini. On the monitor, I had to use the button controls to go to Managaement>Audio and select PC Analog Audio. Also then go to Volume and bump it up. Then in the Mac, I had to go to System Preferences>Sound> and select External Headphones so it sent the audio through to the monitor. Using these selections allowed the volume to be controlled by my Apple wireless keyboard. Only one of the monitors will be able to be the play sound, but it doesn't matter which monitor the video is on. I'm happy with the purchase, the monitors are looking great and I was happy with the price ($175 each).

title: Excellent monitor but no speakers as advertised
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on October 1, 2020
text: EDIT: it appears this monitor has speakers only compatible with Windows. So semi-correct... can’t for the life of me get it to run through my Mac though...Bought this monitor, as many people probably have, because working from home on my 13" laptop long-term was intolerable. This is a gorgeous monitor, lovely and slimline with an unobtrusive base. It takes a decent amount of real-estate on my desk, but the base is low-profile so I end up setting things on it out of the way. It has a good amount of customizable color balance options. The only drawback I have found is the cables must be run either side of the support which presents a cable management dilemma. Not insurmountable though! For $100 give or take, it's a great monitor, but does not actually have speakers built-in as described, so if that's a deal-breaker for you, heads up.That said, the height and tilt adjustments are nice and solid but not too tough to move around smoothly. As long as the speaker thing doesn't both you, I'd definitely recommend this monitor for a cheap and cheerful posture-saver for WFH!

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: Ok, but the volume control is RIDICULOUSLY DIFFICULT
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 26, 2021
text: The picture is great and the screen size is ample.  HOWEVER (and this is a big problem), the volume control is absurdly involved.  there's no manual volume control, nor an volume be controlled by a mouse or key on the connecting device.  Instead, you have to click on one of the buttons at the bottom of the screen.  Then you have to click on the button farthest to the left.  then you have to click the button under the down arrow six times in order to get to "management."  Then you have to click on the left-most-button.  then you have to click down three buttons to get to "audio."  Then you have to click on the left most button.  Then you have to click once on the button under the down arrow.  Then you have to click on the left-most button.  Then you have to click repeatedly on the button under + or - to adjust the volume.  If you pause for too long, the menu disappears and you have to start all over again.  If someone in your house asks you to turn down the sound, beware, beware, beware!  You will be working on it for a long time, while the person who asks you to turn the sound down gets annoyed and you get flustered and have to start all over again, again, and again.  That's not just because there are so many steps for something needed with predictable frequency, but because it's so very easy to forget the instructions I've just given.  What a ridiculous design!

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)

title: There's a chance you may receive one with a defect
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 11, 2022
text: If you scroll among the other reviews with pics, you can see that a lighting issue on the left side of the monitor seems to be a common problem. I bought 2 of these monitors, and sadly 1 of them had this issue as you can see in my photo.My previous monitors were old ones that me & my mom stole from her office, and they still worked perfectly after 5yrs. Disappointing that these brand new screens have problems right out of the box. I will admit though, other than the lighting issue, they have good brightness and color. After going through reddit threads, I've concluded it's not really an HP issue, but rather the fact these are just cheap monitors that probably have bad quality control.Anyways, if you grab one of these, there's a chance you'll end up with a monitor that's just fine. But of course I'm not taking my chances again, and at the time of writing this, I've already bought two Dell S2421HSX's as replacements. Hopefully those one's won't have a lighting issue, but I'd be lying if I said that wouldn't be hilarious.

title: Like a window into another dimension
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
text: This monitor is amazing.To be fair, my previous monitor was absolute $#!+, so perhaps I'm just giddy from the fact I can actually see things now. This HP monitor assembles easily from the package... about 60 seconds including figuring out how it went together (and this while not giving up my masculinity to study the instructions). The viewing space is amazing with the bezel so thin on the top and sides you wonder how it manages to hold the monitor in, and on the bottom with barely enough room for the HP logo. The controls are extremely intuitive, which was a new experience for me with monitors. You push a button, and arrows pop up on the screen indicating which button you need to push next to get what you want.I've only had this monitor for a few days now, and who knows... maybe it will blow up next week. But so far so good!Great job, HP. Maybe now I'll forgive you for beating us on that contract years ago.

I ordered a replacement immediately and the vendor was quick to send me the replacement. meanwhile I suspect it wasn't the monitor but rather the HDMI to USB-C connector I purchased together with this monitor is at fault. text: Had the Hp 24mh 75 hz 1080p non gaming monitor for 2 days.  So far so good. Bought for wife replacing an all in one computer. The HP PC we are using has AMD gpu with displayport (DP). The monitor does also. Connect the DPC from your PC/laptop if it has one to the DP on the HP monitor and you get 75Hz refreash rate. HDMI cable you get gives you 60hz.DPC does not come with the Monitor. So the total cost for me was $122.00. Worth it. Great colors. If you are mainly using for work, Play older games or internet games, this HP is fantastic. #1 monitor sold on Amazon. I can see why. Perfect for my non gamer wife.60hz vs 75hz refreash. Why not use the best setting that the monitor can do. Will make videos/movies flow better. Enjoy monitor with a DPCable if you can!

title: Great monitor but NOT 75hz refresh rate

text: While I still think this is an excellent monitor for the price buyer beware, this is NOT a 75hz refresh monitor!  After using the monitor, checking the user guide, manufacturer site, and engaging through live support with Amazon this is in fact not a 75hz refresh rate monitor.  It is only 60hz.With that being said.  If you are looking for a cheap, excellent monitor for something as simple as work then pull the trigger.  I am considering a second one.  Now do you want to use this monitor for graphic design or gaming? No.  Spreadsheets and email?  Yes. Speakers are a nice touch, nothing special, they are just monitor speakers.  Decent amount of inputs.  Adjustable easy to remove stand.  Monitor works on my Vivo dual monitor stand without any modifications.  I have it currently setup up as a vertical standing monitor and it has been working great.  Despite the free returns and the misleading information I have decided to keep the monitor.  The next price point for better monitors is not something I am willing to shell out my money to get for my simple needs.The reason the item received a 3 star rating is the description.  It is misleading in multiple places for the refresh rate and after pointing out the issue to Amazon the description has not been updated.

title: Great monitors! They DO have 75Hz support!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on January 26, 2021
text: These monitors are great. I got 2 for a dual monitor setup and couldn't be happier. Very thin bezels, good colors, and easy VESA mounting process. In the box is the monitor, an HDMI cable, an audio AUX cord, and a power cord to plug the monitor in.For some reason, a lot of reviews for these monitors are negative because they "don't actually have 75hz refresh rate". They do. The default is 60hz, but there's an easy way to change that (on windows, at least).Right click on your desktop > Click "display settings" > Scroll down and look for "Advanced display settings". Click that. > Under "Refresh Rate", click the drop-down box, and select 74.973 Hz. > Done!Overall this is a great monitor for the cost. Would highly recommend for anyone looking for a solid monitor in this price range.

title: Poor Durability and Terrible Warranty Support
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on May 11, 2021
text: I absolutely loved this monitor and had planned to buy a 2nd of the same model. Unfortunately, within the first 90 days (but after 30 days), I attempted to adjust the tilt for better ergonomics and the screen cracked. I used very little pressure in moving the screen, but the frame is not built with enough durability to prevent the screen from cracking.Speaking with customer service was a horrendous 45 minute waste of time. I was informed that I would have to pay for the repair as it was customer inflicted and the 1-year warranty does not cover the hardware. When I asked what the charge would be, I was asked to provide my email (again), phone number (again), address, the product number, and the serial number (again), before they could tell me what the charge would entail. All of that to be told "I'm only hardware support, I don't know about charges". After expressing my extreme frustration, I was informed that there would be no charge. Then, 3 chat messages later, was told that if there is a charge I would be contacted by the repair department. Either there is a charge or there isn't a charge; and why, are they not able to tell me what the charge is going to be?So now, I'm being sent a box to package my faulty product and send it to them for repair/replacement with no knowledge of if they plan to charge me or not for the repair/replacement. As I use my monitor for online business, this seriously hinders my ability to work for an undetermined amount of time. It is beyond my capable understanding how a company can ask a customer to blindly send them a product and potentially commit to undisclosed charges. What's more is that I cannot make an educated decision as to if I need to purchase another monitor or wait for this one to be repaired/replaced because they refuse to provide me with necessary information, further delaying my ability to work efficiently.Until today, I would have swore by HP products and have always sought them out first because I've been happy with their product line. It is unfortunate that I will now seek other brands due to such a low quality of customer support when things don't go as planned. As a small business owner and online company, it is critical that I can rely on a company to have good customer support. Products break and things happen, I cannot risk poor customer service delaying my business productivity.

product_name: HP 24mh FHD Monitor - Computer Monitor with 23.8-Inch IPS Display (1080p) - Built-In Speakers and VESA Mounting - Height/Tilt Adjustment for Ergonomic Viewing - HDMI and DisplayPort - (1D0J9AA#ABA)
title: This HPmh 23.8-inch Product No. 1D0J9AA has max refresh rate 60Hz (not 75Hz!)
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on April 8, 2022
text: I'm very disappointed that despite Amazon description for this product and numerous reviewers who have referred to 75Hz refresh rate available---it simply is NOT true.  This monitor at 60Hz is not half bad, so despite my aggravation, I won't go through the hassle of returning it to Amazon.  A special note to those who continue to insist that this specific model purchased from Amazon can achieve 75hz maximum refresh, please consider that 1. - you might have a different model, not this specific one Amazon is selling here, or 2. That you're just wrong.  Incidentally, firmware on HP 24mh model that does NOT (repeat, NOT) do 75hz max. is "RIM131".  The manual also states max. refresh at 60hz as does HP customer support.

title: For those who complain about the volume being too low you need to adjust it internally
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 18, 2020
text: Overall the price was right and the screen is great. A few people complain about the speakers being too quiet. The built in speakers are pretty good, just don't expect the quality of the speakers to be as good as $100 external speakers. To adjust Speaker Volume on the monitor itself with HDMI connected (this should work with the 3.5 mm male to male cable as well):• Press any of the buttons on the monitor (not the power)• Select the far left menu icon• Press the second from the left button to scroll down to management• Press the far left button to select• Scroll to audio• Press far left button to select• Select volume• Adjust the max range up to 100%. The default is set on 50%Then use the volume control slider on your PC to adjust the volume as you normally would.

text: This is a solid, good-quality value monitor. Bought it to use w/ a new Mac M1 and the audio volume could not be controlled through the Apple keyboard keys, only on screen w/ cursor. When using the built-in monitor speakers through HDMI or DisplayPort just the same error message: "The selected device has no output controls." 6 hours on support chat and phone with 4 different Apple/Mac reps could not solve the problem. All other audio devices - wired earbuds, bluetooth external speaker - work fine and the keyboard audio controls work. Just not with this monitor using the built-ins. It just does not seem to be compatible with the Mac Mini M1 in this regard. Really inconvenient having to manually adjust audio on screen with mouse and cursor in whatever app is playing audio, iTunes, YouTube, Netflix, whatever. Having to return this monitor that is otherwise acceptable and get another brand with a USB-C port and hope it works. If you have a Mac Mini M1 2020 this might not be the monitor for you if you want volume control from the keyboard. The monitor itself has no external manual volume control. I'd be cautious if you had any M1 Mac and are considering this screen.

title: Bad set-up/menu software, mediocre picture quality...
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2021
text: But, it is cheap and not just in price.  Picture quality on the one we received is just OK if you can look past the light bleed around most of the edges and corners. I could probably live with that because of the price but there are other problems.  The setup/menu software for adjusting the monitor is sparse and some of the features keep changing on their own, for example, the sound setup/menu for the built-in speakers.  Because I am using an HDMI cable for the picture and a line-in cable from an external sound source for the sound the monitor wants to use the HDMI cable as a source for the sound to the speakers so it resets itself every time the computer is shutdown or rebooted.  If I don't go into the menu setup of the monitor each time the drivers are updated or the system is shutdown or rebooted we don't have any sound and we need to change the setup back to using the line-in cable as the source, then it works fine, until the next time (even the computer going into sleep mode causes this problem).Went to HP,s support site only to find one set of drivers and manuals designed to work over a wide array of their monitors and no firmware updates to fix this problem (or anything else for that matter) and they want to blame everything and everybody else as a source for the problem instead of the problematic software that they refuse to acknowledge is the problem.  I guess the old saying "you get what you pay for" is the lesson here.

title: A BAD experience

text: I purchased this monitor because of the reviews and my 25+ years of experience with HP products. It arrived quickly and undamaged. And for 2-1/2 months it was a good purchase.A few days ago I started noticing that when I switched applications a "ghost" would remain on the screen, visible, behind/below the currently running application. (No, my monitor does not stay turned on to a static screen for hours on end.)Today the problem was so bad I contacted Amazon product support. They were as helpful as they could be, including the CS agent holding for 27 minutes for HP Support to answer the phone..........And then the nightmare began.The first person at HP went through a few troubleshooting steps and said he thought the problem may be the graphics card drivers or the card itself. But, because my desktop is a Lenovo he had to transfer me to an HP agent who could help with a non-HP computer.That person did a few trouble shooting steps (after trying to tell me how to hook up my new printer after I explained the monitor issue) and said that the computer was not the problem, it was the monitor and needed to be resolved as an "in-warranty" issue and transferred me to the HP warranty department for resolution.This new agent, after telling me I could "reset" the monitor by holding the power key for 15 seconds then said that the problem was not a warranty issue and said she was going to transfer me back to the department that had sent me to her. At which point, after almost 90 minutes on the phone with HP and almost 30 before that with Amazon, I lost my feces.So, tomorrow I am going to file a warranty complaint through my credit card company, file a lack of customer service and common sense complaint with HP and start looking for a new monitor - NOT HP!Until this issue I would have given this monitor a 4 or 5 star rating. Not now, it is only a 1 star, a monitor should not start failing in less than 3 months. The customer service experience is a negative 5.

title: Less than a year and the monitor has just stopped working
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 3, 2022
text: I bought 2 of these for my office back in March 2021. One monitor gets up to 60hz and the other gets up to 75hz. This is already slow as heck and the difference between the monitor speeds contributed I’m sure. I had to keep them both at 60hz because having them at different speeds caused some serious “stuttering” and “lagging” and other typing, clicking, other processes. The stuttering and lagging was always there but when the speeds were set different, it was even worse.  I was dealing with all that cause I’m cheap but today, while working, the 75hz monitor just died on me out of nowhere. It hasn’t even been a year since my purchase. I tried so many different connectivity solutions and nothing worked. The monitor just wouldn’t pick up the signal from the HDMI cable (3 different ones!). I’m so incredibly frustrated and annoyed, especially considering the price has gone up by $65 since I bought this monitor. This monitor is cheap and unreliable. If you need a monitor for serious gaming or work, don’t waste your money on this one. Shell out the money for a quality monitor or you’ll just be wasting money and taking a risk of having your monitor fail you when you really need it

title: Monitor Blinking Issue Solved
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on February 11, 2021
text: I connected this to my Dell XPS with an NVIDIA GeForce GT 635 video card and my Night Owl HD CMS software would blink (as if it was being turned off and on rapidly) when I mixed hi-res and low-res cameras on the same display screen.  I found on YouTube the solution.  Right click on the desktop, select NVIDIA Control Panel, select "adjust desktop color settings" and change "content type reported to the display" to other than auto-select.  Now it works perfectly.

title: Once very satisfied, now disappointed!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on November 12, 2020
text: UPDATE Nov'22: I've been using two of these monitors for the last two years. Until a week ago, they were brilliant. Now one of them has started to black out. At first it was just a quick1-2 second black out 3-4 times a day. But today , the faulty monitor has been blacking out every few seconds. Super annoying and stressful on the eyes. I've had to shut it down. Drivers are all up to date, power cord connections are solid! Shame on you HP for such a drop in performance in just two years! Changing my review from 5 stars to 2....Oct'20 : I work in user experience and improving a customer's 'out of the box' experience. This monitor and its packaging were truly a user's delight. It took me exactly 90 seconds to get this baby up and running. The user guide was so easy to follow. The monitor itself is lightweight but packs in an excellent display. The speakers are such a joy. I can actually handle work calls without a headset. The low light display setting at night is beautiful. My only issue is that I could raise the monitors to position them above my line of sight (ideal for minimal neck/eye strain) but thankfully, my standing desk comes in handy for this purpose. If you are ever remotely considering this monitor, think no more. Just get it.

title: VESA mountable, but you'll need a bracket
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2021
text: I bought two of these monitors to be mounted to a dual monitor arm setup. Three star review because the vendor should have been clearer about the fact that you will need to buy a VESA bracket separately. To attach the monitor to the dual monitor arm setup I bought, I had to purchase a "Vesa 200mm X 100mm Universal LCD LED Bracket". This is the one I bought:  https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00U3DQO6I/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_asin_title_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1I also had to purchase additional screws because the ones included are too short. I bought M4-0.7 x 18mm screws from my local hardware store which fit my monitor. Good luck! The picture quality and brightness are good. I lowered my overall rating because I specifically bought these monitors because they were advertised as VESA compatible. It was very disappointing to get them home and discover I needed to purchase additional hardware.

title: BROKE AFTER 3 MONTHS - TERRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE, CHEAP MONITOR
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on August 17, 2021
text: It was not a great monitor, but it was serviceable for the price. The screen is not very bright or very sharp. Then the screen died the SECOND I was out of the return window. Contacted Amazon, no help. Contacted HP - the warranty only covers REPAIR not REPLACEMENT. It took me 2 hours to get an HP tech support rep on the line. They made me walk through a bunch of useless time wasting steps about updating the graphics card, and wouldn't listen to me when I kept explaining that it was a HARDWARE issue with the LCD panel. Then they wanted to do a live chat so they could screenshot the damage themselves to open a claim. Now they want to snail mail me a box, have me drop the monitor off at UPS, and wait for it to be repaired and returned. So, now it's taken me a ton of time to get this claim opened, I have to give them my monitor to repair and be without a monitor for the time it takes to get it repaired, and they're going to return the same damaged, defective product back to me. They refused to give me ANY TIME FRAME for repairs. They also hassled me and insinuated that this was my fault somehow, even though it's been connected to a VERSA mount the entire time and never touched. TERRIBLE EXPERIENCE. CHEAP MONITOR. INVEST IN SOMETHING THAT WILL LAST MORE THAN 3 MONTHS. Thanks for wasting my time HP - I'll be disputing this charge with my credit card. P.S. your hold music is absolutely horrible.

title: Don't throw away your satellite speakers!
location_and_date: Reviewed in the United States 🇺🇸 on March 11, 2021
text: First: It's pretty damn cheapo, HP, to send out a product without including a users manual.  I had to go online and print my own.  How much could a leaflet cost - 12 pages double sided... $2 ??  Either absorb the cost or add it into the price.  Making your customers do it is lame.  Second:  You advertise this as "BUILT-IN SPEAKERS – Experience incredible sound and more immersive entertainment with two built-in 2W speakers." Neither I nor Microsoft (after 2 hours) could figure out how to adjust the volume.  It's weak at best at full tilt and it's not even mentioned in the manual - but there's no way to increase it beyond mediocre.  I didn't expect JBL quality boom boxes but this is pathetic sound volume...
